Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 11:06AM Donna1843 wrote: Hi Seasidegirl, When I went for my first mammogram on the 4th of June they took the typical 2 pictures of each breast.  Then they did another 5 or 6 enlargements of the left side.  Then they did an ultrasound to see if there was a mass underneath the microcalcifications that they saw in the mammogram pictures.  The radiologist was excellent.  She really explained things well.  She described what we were looking at in the films and what looked a little suspicious.  Then she gave me 3 options to consider, but I did not have decide right then and there.  One was to follow these mammographically every 6 months for a while.  Two, could have a core biopsy.  Three, could have them completely removed.  I opted to do the biopsy, since my mother had breast cancer and was diagnosed at 43 (and I am 35 now). I feel for you when you say you are frightened.  That is so natural.  But know that having this kind of technology is truly a blessing.  Catching breast changes early on....it is just so important.  I have read over and over that 80% of calcifications are benign too.  I will be thinking about you tomorrow, please let us know how things go. hugs, Donna

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 07:51PM Donna1843 wrote: Estepp, Hi there, Well I survived the core biopsy :)  The staff could see that I was a little nervous and were just so warm and friendly.  I really lucked out and had the same radiologist that I had a month earlier for my mammogram.  She was awesome!  They were very efficient, and answered my many questions.  Heck, I even got to see the calcifications they removed from me in a jar.  The needles to freeze did sting like bee stings, but I did not feel the big one go in at all.  The sound of the tissue removal was a little loud, but after that, all was done.  Then off to be mammogrammed once more and I was on my way. I am glad for the technology.  Now I am resting at home with (many) icepacks and extra strength tylenol.  7-10 days for the results, and I just found out my family doctor is away for the month of JULY!!  Hopefully I can find someone to talk to before August!! Donna

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 10:08PM Donna1843 wrote: Beachlover89 & TonyJ, So sorry that you both have had to go through all of this worry.  I have been reading a lot online.  It is true that there are macro and microcalcifications and that macrocalcifications generally are benign.  I think they worry when the calcifications are a certain size and are in a specific pattern for sure.  And if they are round or irregular shaped.  I would definitely ask for a copy of your mammogram report.  I had to go into my family doctors office to do this, but I am a strong believer in having copies of all reports.  I'm starting a file, just so that from year to year I can look back and understand fully what's going on with things.  Ask them to explain any parts of the report you do not understand, too. Ultimately I truly believe that our healthcare is in our own hands.  If you are concerned, even in the slightest way, it is always within your right to get a second opinion. Keep us posted on how things are going with you both. Donna
Posts.Title: Breast Calcifications azcamm Makratz

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 09:00AM Donna1843 wrote: Valerie, Thank you for the suggestion of the MRI screening.  If there is anything that I am quickly learning...it is that different tests (mammogram, ultrasound, MRI) can pick up different things.  I am nervous about tomorrow...but I feel as though I have made it through this stressful time in part because of the caring people here on this site.  One question........what is the difference between a diagnostic mammogram and a digital mammogram?  I have had the screening mammogram....the diagnostic mammogram (with many pictures of my left side) and an ultrasound. It is very good to know that things cannot always be seen on a mammogram for younger women and for that reason additional testing maybe required. Thank you, Donna
Posts.Title: Breast Calcifications azcamm Makratz

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 04:45AM Donna1843 wrote: Hi Dukemom, Thank you for thinking of me this morning.  I live in Saskatchewan.....is it crazy that I have no idea what time zone that is (central standard time?).  The appointment with the surgeon went well.  He did a bit of an exam and then we went to chat in another room.  I kept playing your words over in my head "feel strong and confident", and I think I held it together pretty well.  I will be going for a stereotactic core biopsy within the next few weeks, hopefully they will have a cancellation sooner, but if not....mid July is okay.  But then it will take 7-14 days to get the test results back.  Can you believe that!!  Sigh.  Guess because of summer that is just how it goes.  He said he will be on holidays the week after next but will be checking in on cases.  LOL.  I think you would have giggled cuz when he said that he wasn't the one doing the procedure, I asked why I was meeting with him then.  Apparently the radiologists are the ones doing it and he just overseas the diagnosis, report and follow up. (all important things as well :)) I guess one of my worries was that I was too small breasted for this procedure to be effective, but he assured me that there should be no problem.  Worst case they would have to do a wire-guided biopsy....which I should maybe do a little more research on.  I also got a script for Ativen...a little something for the monkeys...which I might need the day of the actual procedure to calm the 'ol nerves.  But enough about me :)  How was your night last night?  Did you get any rest? Donna (ps....I totally like the idea of being like scarlet ohara from gone with the wind :))

Donna

Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 07:03PM Donna1843 wrote: KED, Thank you so very much for sharing your story with me.  It brings tears to my eyes thinking that you have gone through so much.  You truly have inspired me to advocate for myself.  Gone are the days of sitting idle waiting....I intend to follow up and not let anything slide.  This is MY life.     I feel so incredibly supported coming here.  Thank you all so much. I had quite the start to my day today, I have to say.  I waited until 8am and then called the specialists' office to see if I could get any information on an appt. time.  To which the receptionist....or whomever it was....said that they had no record of a request/referral for me to see the specialist.  I was a little more than upset, given the week I had last week with worry, so I called my family doctors' office again.  They couldn't understand the mixup.....nor could I...she offered to contact them again and I insisted this time that she call ME back, instead of the other way around.   So it's all setup.  June 27th I go for the consultation with the specialist.  And then we go from there.  I guess once he looks at the films and asks a few questions and maybe talks about the risks of whatever procedure he thinks is best....we'll go from there.  This is so new to me.  Can you describe how the consultation usually goes....I guess I just really want to prepare myself.  And maybe can't. I thought having this date would magically make me feel a ton better.  I'm just as upset as I was before, only now I know it is real.  Having the appointment....not just wondering when I'll be going...now it is becoming more real what is going on here. When you spoke of the monkeys.....I felt like you were describing my life for the past few weeks.  I can so relate. I am sending you best wishes for your surgery tomorrow.  You will be in my thoughts. Hugs back to you, Donna

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 03:59PM Donna1843 wrote: Your words bring me comfort, thank you.  I, too, am smaller so I wonder if they will say the same thing (about doing an excisional biopsy instead).  Did you have to go for any followup after the biopsy?  Did everything come back okay?  What were your BIRAD categories (if you don't mind me asking)? This is just so new to me, I guess that I have a lot of questions.  The family doctor, or the receptionist at the family doctor's office, said that the specialist's office would be contacting me directly for the biopsy appointment.  I have the name of the doctor and have been checking him out online (how he rates etc).  Is it wise to just sit and wait for the call.....is it too pushy to call their office to check on how long I am looking at waiting?  I think they were hoping for me to get in sometime this month....but nothing definite has been said.  From what you have said about the other testing...I feel blessed that I have had so much done so quickly.  I had my annual physical on May 30th and on June 4th I was in for the mammogram/ultrasound. I really am a spiritual person....not overly religious, but spiritual all the same.  I believe that I am being guided.  As though by having this experience, good or bad resulting, I am learning more about myself and those around me.  Now if I could just stop the chattering monkeys at night all would be good :) Donna
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 09:25PM Donna1843 wrote: Thanks Carol, I think that I will call the specialist's office tomorrow.  If you don't mind me asking....do you know what your birad score was?  God.  It's almost like I'm taking a poll or something.  Facing your own mortality, it's really something.  Thank heavens with medical advances we have this opportunity to discover what is going on in our bodies before things are too far along. It's soo bizarre....because even now I remember waiting for the mammogram thinking to myself.....the doctor said to take when mom was first diagnosed and go 5 years earlier for the test.  And I was thinking.....I'm a little early to be here. Now I am glad I went for my own peace of mind.  I will be getting copies of all reports and calling tomorrow.  ttys, Donna
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 02:52AM Donna1843 wrote: Hi, I am 35 and just went for my first mammogram and ultrasound last Wednesday.  The report showed Birad 1 on the right side and Birad 4 on the left.  I feel as though I have been to hundreds of websites, googling anything that I didn't really understand on my radiology report.  It does seem as though the Birad 4 has a high likelihood that it will be benign....but the waiting to even get in for the procedure feels endless.  I think that I have come online to feel validated for feeling so emotional this past week.  My mother was diagnosed with a slow growing breast cancer at the age of 43.  She had a mastectomy...took one round of chemo and quit....and has now survived 14 years. I am scared.  Although everyone around me says not to worry until there is something to worry about...it is much easier said than done. Thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 01:53PM Donna1843 wrote: Thanks so much for responding.  I think that it is at night when I feel the most scared.  During the day I can usually put all of the emotion into a box until I get home from work. But I would be lying if I didn't say I cry at night when the kids are in bed.  I guess that this might just be a part of the process for me. I have had the mammogram....they took 7 pictures (5 of my left because they had to do some enlargement pictures).  Then they did an ultrasound to see if there were any masses growing underneath, and there weren't, thank heavens.  Talk about a first experience; I thought this was gonna be easy breazy clear sailing....just a routine baseline mammo. So after the radiologist came and left 3 times getting these pictures, another lady came in to discuss the films with me.  She said that I had a very small cluster of microcalcifications on my left breast.  They were slightly irregular intermixed with powdery calcifications.  I have no idea what they mean by "interdeterminate microcalcifications" but that was mentioned. She basically gave me 3 options.  Mammogram every 6 months for the next while to chart the growth of the calcifications (cuz this was the first mammo, they have no idea what "normal" is for me), go for a stereotactic core biopsy at the breast health center in town, or get them cut out.  The last option seemed a bit harsh, but the first option seemed a bit passive, given moms history.  So now I wait.  Wait and wait and wait, to see when they can get me in for the procedure I just never dreamed I'd be doing in 2008.  I am not trying to be all "poor me", gosh....if anything I have really learnt that there are just soooooooo many of us out there going through this process. I guess that I am just trying to make peace with it all.  And trying to remember that it is probably all okay.  Worst case....precancer....and you can deal with that with surgery.  Best case, just another mammogram in 6 months. I'm so grateful to be able to express all of this worry somewhere.  Thanks so much for caring and responding. Donna
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 06:58AM Donna1843 wrote: Thank you Dukemom :) Donna
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 10:08AM Donna1843 wrote: Dukemom, Wow.  It must have really been quite surreal looking at the films on the wall for five minutes before your surgeon came in.  I know after they completed the diagnostic mammogram and the radiologist came in to explain her findings.....it felt as though I was in there hearing about somebody elses' films.  Not my own. I guess that all of this is still sinking in.  And hopefully by the time it all sinks in....everything will come back fine. I'm glad that they will discuss all of the options, and then explain why one specific option is better for me.  Asking me to make a choice on tmt when I clearly have no idea....can be a little stressful.  Like when the radiologist said I had three options.  Mammogram once every 6 months for the next while, biopsy, or cutting the little suckers right out.  How do I make a choice without all of the facts.  Maybe I will want to just get them out altogether and be done with it.  I totally agree with your school of thought "when in doubt, take it out." Thanks so much for listening to my worries.  I am wishing you the best of luck for your appointment on the 23rd.  You have been through so much already.  I may just do what you suggested.  Call my doctor for something.  For now I am okay....a little wine here and there to calm the old nerves.  But as the date gets closer for the procedure....I know I am no superwoman. Donna

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2008 10:46PM Donna1843 wrote: Hi greenThumbs and traveler56, The waiting is so hard, I know.  After going for my first mammo at age 35 (mom had breast cancer young), I was told I had microcalcifications and was rated a BIRAD 4.  Then it seemed to take forever to get in to see the surgeon....and I just had the stereo core biopsy on July 9th.  July 16th my family doctor told me the findings were benign.  The ladies on this site are amazing, they really helped me through all of my waiting.  Don't be afraid to ask for something to ease the anxiety as well.  Without a little help of anxiety meds, I don't think I would have slept for weeks!  We are here waiting with you, hugs to you both, Donna
